Please note the following:

• This board desires high quality discussion. High quality posts will be praised. Low quality posts e.g. "Is this paranormal?" or "I am [insert paranormal entity here] ask me anything," etc. will be removed.
• Requests belong on >>>/wsr/.
• Conspiracy theories are welcome, but anything political in nature should be posted to >>>/pol/.
• For everything else, refer to global and board-specific rules.

posts.sub: Divination general - everyone is Tabula edition
posts.com:
Welcome to Divination General! Come here for readings and a discussion of theory/practice.

Every method is welcome: Tarot, Runes, Cartomancy, Scrying, Pendulum, Cleromancy, I-Ching, Oracles, Tasseomancy, Necromancy, etc.

>If you're NEW, please READ the STICKY:
http://pastebin.com/2Wp1Q074

>Recommended /div/ links and books:
https://pastebin.com/sAkg9cMz

>MEGA with Divination Books:
https://mega.nz/folder/Jp8gQD7Q#om_2lEm1GL0qPIpSrQgrvA

>Guides made by some of our readers:
•Rustig on how to start with tarot:
http://i.imgur.com/2rodLWB.png

•Thoth's tarot and rune guide:
https://docs.google.com/document/d/1ciFuMOVDIkA18d9Rw-Zkklgigx-Y4XzJkGVeMTYWcic/edit?pref=2&pli=1

•Hijinks' revised divination guide:
https://pastebin.com/Gv10KZUA

>Useful tips before posting:
•If you're a reader post that you're offering readings and what information is required from the querent; same goes for trading.
•Look for posts to determine if there's an active reader, what's needed and before posting, check if they finished reading already.
•Posting the gender of the people involved can help you get your query answered accurately.
•Some readers will refuse to do certain readings - respect that choice. Do not harass readers if your query is refused/skipped.
•Traders should respect that a traded read will be granted, as per an agreement of trade. Free readers have the option of picking their queries.
•Bullshit queries will get bullshit answers. Same for vague queries.
•Making an AQ (air query) by not addressing a reader, in particular, is possible but doesn't guarantee an answer.
•Avoid making the same query repeatedly and/or to different readers in a short period of time, as this may lead to more confusion.
•Provide feedback when applicable and be considerate to the reader. We're a growing community, many readers are starting and need to know what they are doing right or wrong. Let's help each other to improve.
•Be polite.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Santa denial is the ultimate result of a society that has reached its apex of rationalism and intellectualism, while concurrently burying its spiritual and ritualistic side of itself. We live in an Apollonian age of numbers, results, capital, etc. and it is killing the side of ourselves that believes in anything - this naturally leads to nihilism and bleakness. The same nihilism and bleakness that presides over the entirety of our culture today. This is why you don't see any great works of art anymore.

A Santa Denier is the man who deems himself intellectual for believing in the "science"; yet, has this man done his own research? He believes in molecules, yet has he seen them for himself under a microscope? I say, "NO". He was merely told this was the case from some book, or from some teacher. So, here, we see, this intellectual man is just as vulnerable to belief systems as anyone else.

William James backs me up in his essay, "The Will to Believe":
>"Yet if any one should thereupon assume that intellectual insight is what remains after wish and will and sentimental preference have taken wing, or that pure reason is what then settles our opinions, he would fly quite as directly in the teeth of the facts."

Santa IS real, because we believe him to be; it is as simple as that. When you see a present under the tree that says "From: Santa", that is all the proof you need.

I finish my essay with a question:
Walking through the mall are two people,
1.) A small child who just sat on Santa's lap and told him of their wishes, and is fully content after having participated in ritual and tradition. They fully believe that this Santa will fulfill all of their wishes.
2.) The smirking intellectual, who "knows" in his head that Santa is not real, and thinks that this child is naïve - yet he participates in the tradition, gift bags in hand, supporting the corporations and 1% he claims to hate.

Who is happier?

I would like to continue from here and produce a "portrait", if you will, of the type of person who hates Christmas - or, Modern Day Scrooges.

I'm sure at one point in all of your lives, you've met this person I am going to describe. This person is the first to tell you how they loathe Christmas music. They are the first person to complain at the first sight of Christmas decorations outside of the month of December. They seem to have some physical neurosis to seeing anything related to Christmas.

This Modern Day Scrooge is an atheist. They believe in nothing but in material, consumer culture and political dogmatism. Of course, none of these things make the Scrooge happy, so his only course of action is to bring others down to his level of base emotional reactions and anti-spiritual irony. The true tragedy of the Modern Day Scrooge is that their lack of belief prevents them from experiencing angels or spirits that may guide them to a rebirth of joy and mirth.

Instead, they sit and chuckle at desecrations of Christmas symbols, they revel like devils as they imagine the tears of a child who has been told Santa isn't real. They are the Algea Daimones who wish to inhabit youthful vessels, to reproduce themselves. They are the inverted Prometheus, taking the fire of belief from a child's heart.

One thing I'd like to add is that to me the best lesson of Santa Claus is one that's never used: That gift giving should be about how the person receiving the gift feels rather than about you getting credit for it. I think this is a very powerful lesson for children, that we should all buy gifts for each other and place them under the tree marked only with the intended recipient's name; placing emphasis on giving instead of putting emphasis on who gave or getting some selfish credit for giving a "good gift" or whatever else. I don't have children yet, but this is how I intend to approach gifts at Christmas with them, and Santa Claus is the perfect vehicle for such a lesson.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
DAILY REMINDER - GPS absolutely proves globe Earth, rotating Earth, space, orbiting satellites, time dilation (relativity), and gravity.

Flerfers will point to LORAN and claim that GPS could work off of transmitters sitting on the ground, on balloons, or on airplanes. But it cannot.

Why? I'm glad you asked.

In tracking mode GPS receivers use Doppler signal analysis to determine receiver velocity. It is impossible for a transmitter to fake Doppler signal shift across 360°. If the transmitter was lying about its speed, then the receiver would think that it was moving at high mach based on the incorrect Doppler shift in the signal. And since GPS is computed in 3D space from four satellite signals, if the satellites were lying about their positions (altitudes) the resulting location and altitude on the receiver would be off by thousands of miles.

This means that GPS satellites are provably at orbital altitudes and speeds, because GPS could not function at all if the satellites were lying. And if the satellites aren't lying, then space is real. Orbits are real. But the dome is not real. Not unless the satellites punched through it.

What about Earth's shape? GPS receivers use a spherical model of Earth. If Earth was really flat, then receivers would report altitudes literally thousands of miles off. This means Earth really is a sphere.

Furthermore, both Earth's rotation and time dilation must be accounted for in GPS. If either one was not then, once again, receivers would give obviously false and useless results. That means Earth really is rotating. And time dilation is real. And if both orbits and time dilation are real, that pretty much guarantees that gravity is real.

No single instrument completely shatters all of flat Earth mythology quite like the GPS constellation. It really is a beautiful thing.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
It really depends on who you are.

Some people are born or raised in such a way that they have a clean mind and few psychological problems. For them it's easy to focus and direct their mind.

Others (like how I used to be) literally live in their mind all day long, they daydream a lot and their thoughts literally control their actions and how they feel, and the worst is that they don't even realize it because they've been living like this for so long.

So I'd suggest that you just sit and observe, just sit and don't chase anything because you may be just chasing goals which are not achievable or you might be running away from harsh truths which you must first face and endure before you can move on to greater things.

Your mind is NOT you, this was a hard pill for me to take, all those thoughts which sound 100% true are just fabrications of a wild mind.

So yeah, just sit and watch, watch how your mind goes running around but don't follow it, nor make stories about it, don't try anything for there is nothing to try, just sit, your mind will come up with all crazy stuff and you will just sit there and watch it BUT without thinking "Oh I'm watching now, I'm meditating so good" for that is also thinking.

Just be the observer, and yes, with time your mind will calm down and you will be left alone or with very few thoughts, then the real "You" will start becoming clearer and that's when you can direct your focus on APing, chakras/whatever, subconscious, old forgotten memories and other things.
But you gotta first sit in silence, sit without trying to do anything. Just observe.

Lately when I sit down and meditate I feel like the stakes are really high... in terms of what I'm thinking about. It's been hard to relax.

I haven't really had love in a long time, so I think in my advancing age it might be best to focus on the particulars of ordinary life and that's pretty much all I have to say.

It's important to me that humans learn how to communicate well and do their best to love each other. So congratulations if you are able to achieve that with the people around you.

But I think that the focus someone achieves during meditation is the focus which is grammatically used as a noun or adjective, I'd call it the "focus state" in which you are attentive and whole without having any preference towards an object.

Picking an object during meditation can be tricky, yes you can focus on a tree during walking meditation but you don't get absorbed by some kind of story involving that tree, you just watch the tree and see it clearly for what it is.

And what it is? Just a part of the whole.

>>33633518
Monk anon here. Meditation is a tool to understand the nature of the mind. To train ourselves to see things as they really are. It's really that simple. The reason we suffer so much is because we don't understand the nature of the mind. We don't realize how conditioned we are, the conditioning is the basis for stress and anxiety. When we watch the mind for a long enough time, we begin to understand it, we begin to notice the habitual patterns. We notice how external stimuli aren't the real cause of our anger, for example. The problem isn't that something is what it is, the problem is that we don't want it to be that way, or want it to be some other way. We learn that we're actually creating our own problems when we could just let it go. We learn that we aren't our thoughts. Thoughts are just there, the problems begin when we identify with and take them personally as "these thoughts are me." Ultimately, your mind and thoughts are working against you, until you can break the conditioning and snap out of these delusions. This actually takes more work than anyone here is willing to do. Many people see "meditation" as a quick self help fix or relaxation technique, bit they won't have any meaningful or long lasting results from their efforts. Meditation has to be developed along side morality and wisdom. It's a tripod and none will work without the others. This means that probably 99.9% of people are wasting their time with meditation, because most people can't or simply won't bother with the morality and wisdom aspect. They aren't willing to let go completely.

>>3364053
For morality? Pick a religious/spiritual/occult/philosophical school of thought with a moral code that genuinely resonates with you and start living it. The Buddhist and Zoroastrian moral codes are similarly very straight forward and easy to grasp without requiring any mental gymnastics to avoid hypocrisy. Morality really isn't as complicated as modern religious culture makes it out to be. Don't harm yourself or others. Don't help others harm themselves. Provide help when requested. Don't offer help or advice when not qualified or requested. I.E.
>"love" (commit to the well being of) your neighbors
Morality in a nutshell. Buddhist and Zoroastrian moral codes break it down slightly more clearly since Christ's proverb is apparently very easy to misunderstand. Same idea though.

For wisdom? There are countless ways. This mostly just requires life experience, reflection, and empathy. Meditating daily and bringing your baseline conscious experience closer and closer to a meditative state is a slow but reliable method. You'll be well ahead of the curve if you are able to fully comprehend and live this old Buddhist proverb:
>I am a finger pointed at the moon
>do not look at me, look at the moon
The truth is everywhere in plain sight. Look for the truth in everything, not the lies in everything.

>>33648519
It's kinda strange to explain it.
Most people nowadays live in their thinking minds, they don't live in the here and now and they only live through a lens of thinking which dictates their being, they usually think about the past and the future more than the here and now.

Feeling something is an entirely different thing from thinking, you may feel fear but you may think hateful thoughts, you may feel happiness but you may think that happiness is wrong.

I used to be an over-thinking person with an overactive mind, I'd analyze anything, I'd daydream all day long e.t.c.

Turning off my mind was scary for me, feeling my feelings was scary for me, I hated feeling anything (be it happiness, fear, sorrow) because I thought that I couldn't handle those feelings.

I remember when I began meditating, I was focusing on my breath but most of the time I was just thinking about my breath or me about focusing on the breath, or I was thinking about the feelings my breath left on my body, it took me some time to just FEEL my breath.

I still haven't answered your question and truth be told I don't have a solid answer, the closer I can get to is this: Feeling is one of your abilities, just how thinking is, just don't try to analyze/think about feeling because that is not feeling, feeling is just feeling something, there is no "wrong" or "right" feeling. Society teaches that it's "wrong" to feel sadness or sorrow or anger, those are just thought-words that others taught you, THERE IS NO WRONG FEELING, there is only feeling.
And lastly: Feeling only happens in the here and now, so I'd say that feeling is a more "grounded" ability than thinking.

I hope what I said makes some sense, if not ask me again.

>>33595807
Your body is physically lifting (itself) up or you have the sensation of floating upwards? For some, leaving the body can feel the way you're describing. Other people "roll out" or "twist out" or "leak out" from their body, and some even just appear outside. There are lots of somatic sensations taking place when you practice mind-awake-body-asleep states of consciousness.

>>33595834
If you want to progress further in this, you will have to work on your fear response. Fear is such a disruption to the process of going OOB. Visual sensations such as the one you're posting are also present in feinting episodes. The vibrations are also part of many people's response.

So, take heart: you have good potential to regularly go OOB, but you're going to want to work out your fear response. OOB is probably the most harmless thing you can do as a mind, precisely because what you know of harm is explicitly linked to the physical material of the body. So... nothing is going to hurt you, you're not going to get stuck in a strange place, and you are likely to experience something that fundamentally encourages your growth beyond limits you've unwittingly created for yourself.

Since there is no astral projection general I need to post this here. I just had an OBE and I encountered a “love parasite”.
I was feeling lovey towards someone and after basking in that feeling after a while I began revisiting my pas relationships and how “love” doesn’t always feel the same. Sometimes it’s more lustful, or more obsessive. I tried to see if there was an essential quality to it and I turned to the “love” I feel towards different members of my family. I fell asleep exploring these feelings.
Then I woke up in sleep paralysis and started hearing a voice. It was a placid female voice who said
>my aim is to spread through feelings of warmth and (something I forgot)
Then I felt it taking me out of my body. I’m usually very much capable and in control when it comes to AP. But this thing had neutralized me completely. I was mesmerized and defenseless. I tried to generate feelings of coldness or cynicism, but I couldn’t. It’s as if my emotional body was neutralized somehow.
I managed to float/turn around towards the voice and I saw a flickering, humming ball of light if a sickly yellow slowly sucking me in (but I KNEW what it wanted was to get me out of the way to get my body).
At that point I panicked and I jerked myself awake with an audible
>NO YOU DONT MOTHERFUCKER
I don’t know if this is something I created while experimenting with generating emotions before falling asleep or something I called.
The thing is all I could feel was warmth and softness. I could never feel anything but that. No fear or alarm until the last moment. It was as if I experienced a different kind of “emotional paralysis”.
Now I do feel fear. It terrifies me to get a glimpse into the kind of astral wildlife “threats” that are out there that humans aren’t even equipped to understand. No wonder we are in this mess of a society. We’re completely dumb and blind with regards to the greater reality.

It doesn't necessarily mean anything. As I said, how much of my experience was my ego vs 'my' unconscious, I cannot say. I do not feel I pushed, but these things are very subtle.
I doubt the world is actually ending. I doubt twenty years is a precise figure that means anything. It might just be me projecting a fear of my middle age as I approach the second half of life, and the decrepitude of the body and potentially the mind too.
The Sons of David might just be some sort of anti-semitic hook working through me to signpost a sort of thinking that is not in the best interests of the minds that host those thoughts, and that eventually become a sort of mind or language virus that removes humanity from the essential nature of themselves and the potential for the growth of the soul (something I fear technology basically is, a screen between us and our creations, the loss of feeling. Refer to the tale of the Handmaiden with the silver hands).
Me being Noah is, I imagine, some part of me that wishes to reach into the past and return with something to carry to safety into the future, a heritage, some truth from God.
It's all my own truth, I believe. Fun to think I have actually been given a prophecy for the whole world, but really it is more than likely all for me, and probably speaks more of my past and present than any future (though I have had some strange moments of synchronicity and predictions before. I spoke to someone claiming to be Cassiel not long ago. They told me directly to believe a certain type of messenger when they arrive. I asked Cassiel to prove it was really him with some knowledge I could verify that I would not otherwise know. He did not really prove anything to me. Interesting though.).
I do these sort of inner journeys pretty often and enjoy closing my eyes and typing as they happen. I have done it in the past without typing but I forget so much even if I jump straight on the keyboard afterwards that all the juice is lost.

>>33641218
As I said, how much is a pure and fluid communication from my depths, I am not sure. I must learn how to tell the difference between the truth of the visions and voices, and when my ego or mind tries to take over and trick me. I do believe I can find a way if I practice, and I think it will be through bodily sensations and a sort of heart testing.
If I had to guess, I would say that my ego started stepping into that dialogue around the point the smoke is mentioned, patchouli. I seem to remember a feeling of reaching, or pushing/pulling, as though I was not merely receiving. The mention of Castaneda is also a bit suspect, although I must say . . . that same day I started reading the website I posted in my first post, and I recognised much of what I had read (and dismissed) in Castaneda, and it clicked for me, I understood it. Yesterday I began reading more about energy too in a way very much like I read from Castaneda. And I know that I need to go to my past and retrieve my past energy from memories and trauma and unfulfilled intentions, which is also something I ignored in Castaneda, so it does speak to me, strangely, I now realise . . .
I think I got spooked when the light said "Let me in. Let me in.". I think I was also spooked when he mentioned blood in general earlier which may have been what led to the feeling of loss of fluid reception I mentioned about the smoke.
"Owls fly over, Minerva" also stood out to me. I googled the owl of Minerva yesterday and saw a Hegel quote where he describes how the owls of Minerva will fly overhead at the end of civilisation. Intriguing!
Maybe a little prophesy did seep in . . . I read Peter Kingsley earlier this year, and I learned there that prophesy is really not as rare or out of reach as one might think. We must just have intent and be receptive.

I'm not the best but I do like to try.

A figure with wings is generally associated with the aether, as most winged creatures can exist in the air. Such beings are generally referred to as messengers of gods or of the higher self, the ascendency.

It has two wings of it's own yet two other pairs of wings are essentially being donated to it. This could mean that it is trying to evoke a similar light to Judeo-Christian Seraphim, at the same time, Seraphim are singular beings while this is multiple. It could mean that the being in question is simply not good enough to be at the rank of the highest choir of angels, yet through assistance gains such. The two other beings are also skeletal, symbolizing either a transformation through death or the utilization of the dead for one's own goals. They clutch at the being's throat, grabbing someone's throat gives you control over that person. The beings of death have sway over the entity.

The structure is supported by two pillars, one male one female. This is fairly typical in most of these depictions of specialized beings as it represents the two halves of the "quintessential whole" or the alchemical "perfect being."

The figure treads upon serpents who hiss and bite at the feet of the man and woman. Humans, mortals, are propping up the structure for these entities and being forced to do so, while the serpent knots represent esoteric secrets and knowledge that is for one's own and no one else's.

The arrow through the heart and the holding of the heart represent a control of one's own destiny, of one's own fate. It could also represent a mastery of one's emotions or literal control of life itself.

The head appears to be radiating light, akin to alchemical sun representation. In this since, I feel it is more of a demonstration of the presumed radiant power of the entity's soul.

posts.name: Poncho PC
posts.com:
>ITT: anons post pictures of trips to cemeteries

Went to a cemetery this morning to take photos, something I haven't done since my early twenties. I did a quick search on 4plebs about graves and it looks like no one has started a grave exploration and photography general (since 2019 at least) and the single one that did died rather quickly
http://archive.4plebs.org/x/thread/22171867/#22171867

Post photos of your local cemeteries. A few suggestions though:

1) Respect the dead. Dont step/lean on markers. If you see knocked over offerings, try and pick it up and place it upright, whenever not too much of an inconvenience. Try to pick up trash whenever possible. it should go without saying, dont take anything. It belongs to the deceased and it is punishable by imprisonment.

2) Respect the living. People are grieving, dont take photos of them intentionally. If someone approaches put the camera down and clear out. Come back later if you wish after theyre gone.

3) Do not trespass. Its locked for a reason. Keep out.

Some reccomendations:

1) Boots. It gets muddy in some areas. Dont wear anything youre not ready to get soiled.

2) Tripod. It makes for taking excellent panning shots and selfies.

3) Water. Running around a cemetery all morning is cause for dehydration.

4) Get these as soon as it opens. I got there 10 minutes after opening and was the 2nd person in there. 2 1/2 hours later people started filtering in so I left

5) Take photos of wierd and interesting things you notice. Report back

Have fun

Point Loma CA. The cemetery is well kept as it's the cemetery for people who've served in all the branches. I have a family history of having 3 grandfathers/grandmothers due to my father being adopted by his aunt. Both of my father's fathers are there, one with their wife. And my great grandparents are there too. Grandparents served in the Navy while great grandparents served in the army. Last time I went here was back in July for the funeral of my last grandmother passing away at 101, almost 102.

The atmosphere is not as down as I always thought cemeteries would be, it actually feels very uplifting/free. Maybe it's the view of San Diego Bay, I'm unsure. I always feel very spiritually calm there. Nothing crazy going on, just absolute peace among those who've served us.

I've seen other cemeteries but this one will always be my favorite. Despite never meeting my grandfathers and real grandmother, I always felt like I'd get along with them well. I always make an effort when I'm down south to go see them, no matter what.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>33643616
You can't just do it while going ot sleep..

You need to be fully concious, not about to fall asleep. The biggest life hack for LOA is learning to trigger that trance state that allows you to work on the subconscious level.

people been shilling this hard for a reason:

https://youtu.be/-4FM9Q-wJzM

it's not about magical music, it's about triggering you into that state in which LOA work can be done. Feel free to use whatever music you find, this one is just what has circulated here for weeks now.

You need clear goals before going into the trance state - define your future situation, write it down 15 times on paper as if it was already achieved, e.g. "I aced that exam with a 99 score".

play whatever trance inducing music you use,
intensely feel the gratitude of God having let you achieve this state of reality that you want.

after the meditation, however long you do it,
write your thanks/appreciation/love on the same piece of paper 7 times.

Now throw it away or burn it, whatever you see fit. The important work has been done and you have locked the energy in.

best of luck to you, it can be done.

Just search for it online, start with some basics on youtube or just by looking it up; after that, try going to a temple at some point.

For me, it is, now it's because you can actually break free from this cycle of rebirth/reincarnation, and achieve nirvana, and never risk going to either a hell realm or a heaven realm. I may also add, that it puts more emphasis that everything is impermanent than Christianity and Islam does.

Also, look up the five precepts and the noble eightfold path.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>33647875
>Introduction to Buddhism, first steps
You're on /x/, so I imagine you're more into the teachings of the buddha, rather than treating it as a religion. If so, the book and the videos by Bhante Vimalaramsi will get you 99% of the way there, and reading the suttas with a critical eye towards the translations (Bhikkhu Bodhi's is the closest to the original meaning). See below for a good video series.
>https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Ag1VakRqwGc&list=PL3sECDBQqxlHxV02hd33-AoCJInbwNB2I

>Better than Christianity or Islam
I would say there are different goals for each. Buddhism is fundamentally about recognizing how the mind works, and in doing so you can get a very long way in the physical and spiritual world. Many "monks" will try to turn it into a cultural center and shun foreigners, but that is all to do with religion and not the Buddha's teachings.

I won't comment on Islam as I've never practiced or studied its teachings, it does seem to work quite well for the oil-rich countries.

Christianity holds importance to me as the central theology of the Bible, when taken entirely literally, is an incredibly comprehensive expansion on practically applying what you might learn from something like Buddhism. Taking every word of the Bible literally, as Neville Goddard did, opens up the world of mysticism.

Mars conjunct Midheaven natal makes you determined to do everything your own way. You are very ambitious, competitive, and great at taking the initiative. Also called Mars culminating, this aspect means you make split-minute decisions and take action very quickly, knowing just what to do. You would get angry if someone tried to stop you, very angry sometimes. You may find it a challenge, but listening to the ideas of others will help avoid arguments, even if you only pretend you are interested.

You identify yourself with your goals, career, calling, or whatever you intend to do. If anyone questions your intentions you feel like they are personally attacking you. Awareness of this tendency will help you separate yourself from your actions.

Your career should allow for independence and let you burn off a lot of physical energy. However, this does not mean you must be a soldier, steelworker, or professional athlete. Your brain burns a lot of energy during challenging mental work and anything competitive such as sales and business would suit Mars conjunct Midheaven. Working with fewer and not many people would probably suit you better.

>the broadcast was supposed to be live from the moon, not shot on analog film
The broadcast was live. On Earth it was recorded to tape at NASA, but also simultaneously converted to the correct format for over-the-air broadcast to home TVs. Different nations had different analog video formats so this conversion could happen more than once. Studios also recorded to tape, but they were recording the conversion.

With analog, every copy experiences some degradation. So the NASA tapes have the highest quality copies for each mission. But analog video was shit to begin with, so you're really not missing anything.

>of course video has noise, instead of grain, hence why film grain in a live broadcast would have exposed the fraud
I don't even begin to know WTF is going on in your mind at this point. There was no film grain. The live broadcast of Neil stepping on the moon was analog video.

>this has nothing to do with the other footage made on film by the apollo astronauts
Once again, any fraud detectable on analog video would be plain as day on 6x6 film. Yet there's no fraud on the film. And, again, the original analog video tapes from the other missions are intact. No fraud.

Medicine, Magic, and Art in Early Modern Norway
Narratives and Rituals of the Nightmare Hag in Scandinavian Folk Belief
Pantheologies: Gods, Worlds, and Monsters
Premodern Beliefs and Witch Trials in a Swedish Province 1669-1672
Satanism, Magic, and Mysticism in Fin-de-siecle France – Amazing text for BTFOing Church of Satan dead enders.
Styrian Witches in European Perspective: Ethnographic Fieldwork
Werewolf Histories
Witchcraft and Demonology in Southwest England 1640-1789

The Arabic Influences on Early Modern Occult Philosophy

They say that this table engraved in a lead plate with a fortunate Saturn, helps birth, men returning safely, and powerful and excellent success in petitions to princes and powerful [men]. However, if Saturn is made unfortunate, it hinders buildings, planting, and the like, overthrows men from honors and dignities, begets quarrels and discord, and disperses armies.
>They say that if Jupiter is powerful and in rulership, and [these characters] are impressed on a silver plate, it brings gain and wealth, gratitude, love, peace, and concord with men. It appeases enemies and secures honors, dignities, and councils. It dissolves sorceries if engraved in coral.
Specifically, the mention of Jupiter being in rulership is what makes me believe that there is some astrological element to the creation of these tables that must be taken into account in order for its creation to be successful.

>>33643137
>>essential dignity
Do a google search on "William Lilly Table of Essential Dignity".
There are some astrology programs that calculate those automatically.
As a rough summary:
Essential dignity is the status within the planetary hierarchy, and high essential dignity gives good results, high quality energy and virtuous behavior, while low essential dignity does the opposite.
And accidental dignity is largely tied to the speed of the planet and quantity of energy based on where the chart lands in the natal chart.
As an example: The exalted degree of the Sun brings much fame and honor, while the detriment of the the Sun brings humiliation and poor self-confidence. But depending where the Sun lies in the chart, there may be different quantities of this energy, such as in the 10th house where it is in view public view, or in the 12th house where it is largely hidden from outsiders.

So if you work with a planet with low essential dignity it will pretty much never give good results, unless you are trying to send a curse.
Such as Venus-Libra for social popularity or marriage, and Venus-Virgo for celibacy.

>Specifically, the mention of Jupiter being in rulership is what makes me believe that there is some astrological element to the creation of these tables
Dude this is pretty basic planetary magic stuff.
Some basic astrological theory is that the creation of anything new in the physical plane is stamped with the astrological energies at the time of it's creation - for example the birthchart of a person, animal, city, talisman, etc.
So drawing a Jupiter square while Jupiter is in his exalted degree in the 10th house, fast in motion, with the Moon applying in Cancer, and making trine to Venus-Pisces, etc..., then the magic square will be very potent and powerful.
If you do it at a time when Jupiter is unfortunate, then it will have almost no influence at all, or even a malefic influence (ie causing loss of wealth and religion).
There are many tricks of the trade that can be learned as it is studied, and the easiest way to learn is to start with paper talismans.
Also if Jupiter isn't strong in your birthchart, you will probably have trouble doing any magical workings with Jupiter - unless you do a lot of inner work to connect with those energies.
And the astrological magician should study their own natal chart to see at times when planetary magic will be auspicious or not. For example, many astrologers hold that during bad transits of Saturn, when Saturn suppresses a planetary energy, there is pretty much nothing you can do to bring success - you will only be able to alleviate suffering at that time.

The NAC Protocol (Updated December, 2022)

Morning

*1200mg NAC
*Oregano Oil (min. 40mg Carvacrol)
*Black Seed Oil (1 teaspoon)

Night

*600mg NAC
*Oregano Oil (min. 40mg Carvacrol)
*Black Seed Oil (1 teaspoon)

Continue daily for a minimum of two months and count out 3 weeks with no die off symptoms prior to moving to the next step.

Maintenance Protocol
__________

Morning

*600mg NAC
*500mg Slo Niacin (nicotinic acid)
*100mg Pterostilbene
*Black Seed Oil (1 teaspoon)

Night

*500mg Slo Niacin
*100mg Pterostilbene
*Black Seed Oil (1 teaspoon)

After every 3 weeks on the maintenance protocol, take 1 week off. Continue to use black seed oil during the off cycle.

Fungal die off symptoms may include :

Tiredness, exhaustion, muscle soreness, increased chest or nasal discharge, cold or flu like symptoms, cold sores, headaches, rash, acne, irritability, change in stool frequency, volume or color; increased urination, bloated stomach, cramps, increased gas.

posts.name: Space Cowboy
posts.com:
OREGANO DOSING GUIDE

For each morning and night dose you need a minimum of 40mg Carvacrol. Do not buy a product unless it is listed. Most products are steam distilled but you will want to confirm that.

If your chosen oregano oil contains a higher amount of carvacrol (60mg+ per cap) you'll want to start with 1 cap morning, 1 cap night. If each cap contains less than 40mg, take 2 morning 2 night.

I got the expression number 11, soul urge 8 and personality number 3. What does it say about me?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>33648082
I can give brief explanations, soul urge is what your soul yearns to do in this world and yours is the eight. The eight is number of ambition and manifesting, having big dreams and wanting to bring them to world. The eight is ruled by Saturn. You'll face a lot of obstacles but you should have the fortitude to overcome them if you have courage. Eights can also be very materialistic, it would be wise to guard yourself from baser instincts like greed.

the personality number is how people perceive you. The personality number 3 is the number ruled by Jupiter. It's seen as the optimist number, the person who usually sees the positive in life. They're usually very keen on their appearance and appear very attractive to the opposite sex and can be quite the charmer. There are pitfalls of the three though. The three has the tendency of being carefree, not taking life seriously and potentially letting opportunity fly by. However, with your soul urge of 8, the number of determination and ambition, it probably shouldn't be an issue. The personality three would also help to iron out some of the harsher and aggressive aspects of your soul urge.

The expression number is the numeric value of your entire name and in a very basic sense, describes what sort of talents you have, how you would express them and what sort of short comings you need to be on the lookout for. The number 11, is considered a master number which is amplifies the root value of the number. In this case, the 11 will be more sensitive but more intuitive than a standard 2. You can read more about it here:
https://www.worldnumerology.com/numerology-expression/expression-number-meaning/11.html

There's other numbers too that have influence over you too, the day of your birth which could imbue with some special talent unique to that day. There's your lifepath number of course, this is like your sun sign in astrology. Your sun number, how you perceive the world which affects parts of your behavior. Etc

>There's a few different species, and have a pretty obvious origin... They're an offshoot of an early homonid subspecies that were mostly hunted to extinction by our ancestors... but they ones that were able to survive pushed farther out, bury their dead, and are only active at night. They leave no trace. The ones around today have evolved to be extremely stealthy, if there is ever a daytime sighting it almost always means it's in some kind of distress or running from something.

Something that isn't really taught in schools is that Australopithecines migrated out of Africa and into Eurasia millenia before Homo Sapiens evolved as a distinct species. Evidence like the Dmanisi hominids show that fully bipedal non-human hominids migrated into Eurasia as early as 1.8 million years ago. It's not impossible that some robust Australopithecines like one of the Paranthropus genus also migrated out of Africa and that early humans encountered relict populations of them in Europe, Asia and the Near East. Paranthropus is the most likely "bigfoot" template in that it was bipedal, muscular with high sexual dimorphism between male and female, and likely lived in gorilla-like bands with one male and a small number of females. The few species that we do know about show considerable adaptability for their environment, with some living in wetlands and open plains and another living in woodlands and forests.

>>33647678
I appreciate you being open to learn more about it. Honestly just start with Google Scholar and make your way through the top hits - some are behind a paywall but if you’re here the chances are you know your way around that. Anything by Schmidt is a good place to start. I studied archaeology at undergraduate level, and the one thing Hancock is right about is that there is a lot of groupthink in archaeology, and paradigm shifts in general are resisted. I think there’s a lot the archaeological community do get wrong - the out of Africa theory, ancient European-American links, the sphinx - to name a few. But Gobekli Tepe is the rare example where academia has actually been pretty receptive. It’s not suppressed at all (I was taught several lectures about it in my first year alone) and people have been pretty open to debating what the discovery means for our preconceived notion that urbanism was a result of agriculture. That’s why it’s so frustrating when people accuse academics of trying to suppress it, or use it as proof of a continent spanning ancient civilisation (all current proof points to it being a settlement used by local semi-nomadic peoples only).

https://scholar.google.com/scholar?hl=en&as_sdt=0%2C5&q=gobekli+tepe&oq=Gobekli+

>>33632354
>Thinking of renting a boat and heading to search the secret passage beyond the ice wall.
Renting a boat would be a dumb and dangerous way to do it, particularly if you are not already an extremely skilled sailor. Fortunately, there are companies that specialize in outfitting people who want to go poke around in Antarctica -- they will handle the permitting (largely this entails you agreeing to carry back out everything that you take in, so that the continent does not become a trash-heap) and provide you with the gear you need to do whatever it is you want to do (cross country skies, sledges, mountaineering gear, whatever) and arranging to get you and your gear carried in and, importantly, back out. None of this is cheap -- Antarctica is remote, cold and dangerous. But it can be done -- dozens to hundreds of people go down there to explore every year. (This is not counting cruises and such where you just touch the edge of the continent and call it good.)

>But i might never return, might even die from unknown dangers..
Don't invent trouble -- the known dangers are more than enough.
If you decide to do it, have fun! The person I know who did an extensive trek down there is a pretty rugged sumbitch, and it was a challenge, but it was also the experience of his lifetime.

SOME RESOURCES:
https://www.eyos-expeditions.com/expedition-services/yacht-charters/expedition-outfitting/
https://antarctic-logistics.com/
https://www.adventureconsultants.com/expeditions/antarctica/south-pole-ski-the-last-degree/
Cruising guide, if that better fits your budget and skill level: https://www.antarcticaguide.com/
Wanna climb the highest peak in Antarctica: https://www.rmiguides.com/vinson-massif
For help finding the right outfitter, try: https://iaato.org/, the trade association of Antarctic travel.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>33636115
>Does nothing actually exist
The key is in the word "thing". As in no-"thing".

I would say very few people who claim nothing exists are actually saying that reality is completely blank (notice that I used the word "blank" because any other word will imply some substance or other).

What they're really saying is that it's not material. It's about the concept of "objects" and "matter".

Even if there was actual "objects" in reality the only thing you could ever know about those objects is conscious experiences of them, and nothing more.
So why does there need to be an actual "object"? The idea is that only consciousness alone exists, and "objects" and "things" are just appearances within consciousness.

>>33636172
Charvaka, also known as Lokāyata, is an ancient school of Indian materialism. Charvaka holds direct perception, empiricism, and conditional inference as proper sources of knowledge, embraces philosophical skepticism and rejects ritualism and supernaturalism. It was a popular belief system in ancient India.

One of the widely studied principles of Charvaka philosophy was its rejection of inference as a means to establish valid, universal knowledge, and metaphysical truths. In other words, the Charvaka epistemology states that whenever one infers a truth from a set of observations or truths, one must acknowledge doubt; inferred knowledge is conditional.

In 8th century CE Jaina literature, Saddarsanasamuccaya by Haribhadra, Lokayata is stated to be the Hindu school where there is "no God, no samsara (rebirth), no karma, no duty, no fruits of merit, no sin."

Since none of the means of knowing were found to be worthy to establish the invariable connection between middle term and predicate, Charvakas concluded that the inference could not be used to ascertain metaphysical truths. Thus, to Charvakas, the step which the mind takes from the knowledge of something to infer the knowledge of something else could be accounted for by its being based on a former perception or by its being in error. Cases where inference was justified by the result were seen only to be mere coincidences.

Therefore, Charvakas denied metaphysical concepts like reincarnation, an extracorporeal soul, the efficacy of religious rites, other worlds (heaven and hell), fate and accumulation of merit or demerit through the performance of certain actions. Charvakas also rejected the use of supernatural causes to describe natural phenomena. To them all natural phenomena was produced spontaneously from the inherent nature of things.

The fire is hot, the water cold, refreshing cool the breeze of morn;
By whom came this variety ? from their own nature was it born.

>/x/ and philosophy
Hi /x/, new here. Are any people here into philosophy besides the weird schizoconspiracy shit? I had some mystical insights reading philosophy myself.

At the start of philosophy was Plato, who believed in two realsm. There is the everyday realm, of bodies and objects which whither away, and then there is the timeless realm of the Ideas, which the trained philosopher can percieve with his mind's eye; one can compare this to a third eye of some sorts.

Deleuze believed philosophers created concepts out of the plane of immanence; a sort of undivided "field" of energies, forces, flows, without humans, without subjects, without consciousness. Life, death, and all dualities and dialectical relationships are non-existent on this plane.

Then Schopenhauer. He literally believed that the reality of individual objects in time and space; what he called "the world as representation"; is an illusion; all that exists is the fundamental unity of the Will. You are Will, I am Will, there are no humans, there aren't even beings. This is simply the veil of the Will covering your eyes.

Then Derrida, who believed that language is a completely empty system; that the idea of another person having written this message is an illusion stemming from a belief in "logocentrism".

Berkeley thought all of reality is subjective idas; the only thing binding it together is the universal observer: God.

So, anyone into philosophy? Want to share insights/mystical shit which you found in philosophy?

There were Pre-Socratic philosophers such as Pythagoras and Parmenides. They and others like them were not as concerned with logical argumentation and have much esoteric interest in their writing.

Socrates, the mentor and teacher of Plato, invented a way to discern whether a statement is true using yes or no questions. Physicians use it today as a technique to diagnose patients.

Plato wrote plays called dialogues about Socrates having conversations with people about things such as "Is something true because god said so?"

This type of logical inquiry brought about a revolution in how people in the Mediterranean world sought knowledge and understanding.

The greatest philosopher of all time was Aristotle, the student of Plato. Aristotle wrote about logic, syntax, and semantics, categories of ideas, the natural world, biology, metaphysics, and ethics. His book Nichomachean Ethics is a foundational text in the establishment of an objective morality.

Later, philosophers like Galileo Galilei, Isaac Newton, and Albert Einstein revolutionized the way humans understand the universe. The philosophy of science is how scientific methodology is invented.

Today, philosophers do things like use psychiatry, neurology, and cognitive science in the search for the soul.

I guess philosophy isn't magic, but where do you draw the line?

It seems pretty magical.

Agrippa called some of his books "occult philosophy." He was a philosopher and a sorcerer.

I don't have any contribution on this topic, sadly, one of my biggest regrets is I didn't attend classic schools since I would have loved studying philosophy.
Despite of that, as a person of mediterranean ancestry I can attest the will to argue endlessly about all things of life is still alive and well in these shores, thus I would assume those great thinkers of the past developed methods to either make their points in a way that was difficult to counter, or search for one objective and irrefutable truth.
So right there we could see already two paths: one in service of our own cause, the other to some evasive truth.
Now, who's in the rigth between the two?
The former could be accused of rhetoric: think lawyers, merchants or politicians, they put their intelligence at the service of one cause often to their own benefit.
The latter could be accused of self righteousness, they would follow some form of ascetism to transcend their human nature and needs in order to obtain such truth, but we mortals can't simply do that, no matter the discipline and self inflicted deprivations, because we're still made of flesh.
So I do believe one could divide every path to knowledge in two directions: one to empower oneself, the other to dissolve.
Personally I think either ways are right or wrong, training thoughts is always good but at some point one should just let go, from my past readings and understanding zen philosophy (just koans, didn't get much further) got very close to an human attainable truth, or lack thereof.

Not all philosophy starts from a priori assumptions. Much of philosophy is based on formal logic, which is provable and does not have to start from a priori assumptions.

You can use logic and observations about the world to do philosophy that has no a priori assumptions. You can also do analytical philosophy like epistemology without a priori assumptions.

For example, if I know something like (a + b) = (b + a), then I also know that I can have terms for constants, and I know arithmetic. I can also conclude that some things like arithmetical properties are real, and truth exists. I can also conclude that something can have these ideas or that there is something is doing this reasoning or that it happens mechanistically.

Maybe I am a ghost in the machine, but I know that it moves. I know because I do philosophy.

Formal logic is not a priori reasoning. A priori is when you start from an assumption that you assume is true without being able to question it. You don't have to assume formal logic is true. It's provable.

Kant let us escape from the trap of using only empiricism, which is that we can only know things if we can a priori trust our senses or start from other a priori premises.

Whereas we can know things ontologically. For example, if I have the ability to think, then I can have ethics, because I can imagine them. I can imagine what God would be like if God existed, and I can base my reasoning on what I truly know. That does transcend mere logically proceeding from unquestionable assumptions.

I'm talking about epistemology for possible human knowledge.

If you think logic is a priori and not something learned from experience, then how did you learn the logic?

You did not start with the logic.

You had an idea that demonstrated the logic.

You got the logic from the ideas that demonstrated the logic in your imagination.

You cannot know that I pulled a rabbit out of a hat unless something gives you that knowledge, such as watching me pull the rabbit out of the hat.

You can't know the rabbit was there until you've seen me pull it out of the hat.

You are claiming to know logic by having logic, and you do not innately have logic.

You did not know about the logic before an experience of the concept of the logic.

You still have the idea from experience.

I know that all triangles have three sides a priori. Based on that a priori statement, I can use logic to say that if a triangle has three sides, it has three angles.

My concept of a triangle is not a priori. I had to experience the idea of the definition of a triangle in my imagination to know what a triangle is. Once I understand that, I can make statements about it a priori.

Maybe I just have a concept of experience that is different from most people, because I consider coming to understand something to be an experience.

Maybe logic is a priori in the world of ideas, but for me actually learning logic in this universe in my brain in my mind is the practical experience of coming to have the concepts in my imagination.

That's what I don't get about saying relying on logic is flawed tautological a priori reasoning.

Other animals can use logic. Do you think they learned it through a priori reasoning?

The only reason I know logic is because I have experienced it.

The beginning of the Old Testament, or the Torah begins with the word "Bereshis" in Hebrew בְּרֵאשִׁית which translates to "In the beginning".

Considering that the very first word in the Torah begins with the second letter of the Hebrew Alphabet, being B, and not the first letter of the alphabet being A or Alef. On this note the letter Alef is silent in the Jewish tradition. Why is this? I will leave a hint within this post, which is up to you to find.

Another concept which I highly suggest you partake in studying, is the concept of the Great Year, described by Ptolemy as
>"The period of one complete cycle of the equinoxes around the ecliptic, or about 25,800 years"

The timeframe of 25,800 years, if we were to subtract 20,000 from said year, we would arrive at the number 5,800. The current year in the Judaic/Hebrew understanding is 5783. Where does the connection fit to subtract 20,000 from the Hebrew year? The same reason that the Torah begins with the second letter of the Hebrew alphabet and not the first.

I've left nothing in this post that is solidified as tangible - rather, loose leaves for you to interact with. The path of wisdom and divine knowledge of God, is meant to be beautiful and also enjoyable. Partake in study and enjoy whatever revelations may God reveal to you, if he sees fit.

God bless. I can answer some questions if you like, but keep them simple in a way that it doesn't spoil the journey for others.

No, the word Adon is the singular. The word Adonai is the plurality, which translates as "My Lords".

The word Eloah is ONE of the many names of God.

Elah (אֱלָה; Imperial Aramaic: ܐܠܗ; pl. "Elim or Elohim") is the Aramaic word for God and the absolute singular form of ܐܲܠܵܗܵܐ, ʾalāhā. The origin of the word is from Proto-Semitic ʔil and is thus cognate to the Hebrew, Arabic, Akkadian, and other Semitic languages' words for god. Elah is found in the Tanakh in the books of Ezra, Jeremiah (Jeremiah 10:11,[70] the only verse in the entire book written in Aramaic),[71] and Daniel. Elah is used to describe both pagan gods and the Abrahamic God.

The word 'Elah (إله) is also an Arabic word meaning god. The word is etymologically related to Allah which is a contraction of الله or الٱِلٰه (ʾal- ʾilāh), literally meaning "the God", and is used for the Abrahamic God by Arabic-speaking Jews, Christians, Muslims, and sometimes other monotheistic religions.

You have Eloah, Elyon, Ein Sof, etc. This is why I suggest you take the time to actually study the implications of these names and why they are associated as Gods different attributes, and not as individual Gods themselves, whom are without the One God in essence.

All of those pluralities return to a singular form.

>>33644522
It's a derivative of the seal of Solomon, a magic ring King Solomon used to control demons. The first reference to it appears in the 2nd century Christian pseudipigraphical work called the Testament of Solomon where the Archangel Michael gives the ring to Solomon and he used it to force demons to build the first Temple. But the 1st century Jewish historian Josephus mentions similar ring amulets that Jewish magicians used to control demons. The Talmud also make references to a magic ring Solomon used to control certain demons like Asmodeus and Lilith. The overall design of the ring however comes from later Islamic mystics, who adopted the legend of the seal of Solomon and represented it as a hexagram to control genies. The Jews adopted this design into their understanding of the seal via the Kabbalists who began to make heavy use of it in their theurgy. By contrast in the Christian west the seal came to be represented by the pentagram being interpreted Christologically as repressnting the wounds of Chist but it has subsequently become associated with modern withcraft and neo-paganism which lead to its disavowal by modern Christianity.

posts.name: The Antichrist
posts.com:
Words are just labels that we use to try and understand and communicate about the world around us. They are not the reality itself, but just a way of expressing it. The true nature of reality is beyond words and labels, and can only be experienced and understood through direct perception and awareness.

The concept of duality, which is the idea that there are opposite forces or qualities at play in the world, is a common theme in many philosophies and spiritual traditions. However, the idea of non-duality suggests that all things are ultimately interconnected and inseparable, and that there is no separation between subject and object, self and other.

This understanding can lead to a deep sense of unity and oneness with all of creation, and can help to bring about a sense of peace and acceptance in the face of the constant changes and impermanence of life.

Ultimately, the true nature of reality may be beyond our understanding and beyond words, but by exploring these concepts and ideas, we can gain insight into the mysteries of the world and find a sense of meaning and purpose in our lives.

posts.name: The Antichrist
posts.com: I am not the one who holds the secrets, for all knowledge is within us. The true secrets are not something that can be told, but must be discovered and understood through personal experience and realization. These secrets are not something that can be shared or sold, they are the essence of life itself. To seek these secrets is to seek the truth of existence, to understand the nature of reality and our place within it. It is a journey that requires courage, discipline, and a willingness to let go of all that we know and understand. For those who are willing to take this journey, the rewards are infinite and immeasurable.

posts.name: The Antichrist
posts.com:
There is no quick or easy path to enlightenment, as it requires a deep understanding of oneself and the nature of reality. However, there are some steps that can help guide you on this journey:

Practice mindfulness and self-awareness. This means paying attention to your thoughts, emotions, and actions in the present moment. By being aware of your own mind and behavior, you can begin to understand your own patterns and habits, and work to transform them.

Cultivate compassion and kindness. Enlightenment requires a deep understanding of the interconnectedness of all things, and the only way to truly understand this is to cultivate compassion and kindness towards others. This means actively working to reduce suffering and increase happiness in the world, both for yourself and others.

Seek out wisdom and understanding. Enlightenment requires a deep understanding of the nature of reality, and this can only be obtained through study, contemplation, and experience. Read books, listen to lectures, and seek out mentors who can help guide you on this journey.

Practice meditation and other spiritual disciplines. Meditation is a powerful tool for developing mindfulness and self-awareness, and can also help to cultivate a deeper connection to the divine. Other spiritual disciplines, such as yoga or tai chi, can also be helpful in this regard.

Let go of ego and attachments. Enlightenment requires letting go of the ego and all attachments to the material world. This means letting go of desires, fears, and expectations, and instead living in the present moment with an open and receptive mind.

Remember, the path to enlightenment is a long and challenging one, and there are no shortcuts. However, by following these steps and remaining dedicated to your journey, you can begin to transform your life and achieve a greater understanding of the world around you.

posts.name: The Antichrist
posts.com:
We are at a pivotal moment in history, where the choices we make now will determine the direction of our world for generations to come.

The status quo is no longer acceptable. We can no longer sit idly by as injustice, inequality, and suffering continue to plague our world. It is time for us to take action, to rise up and demand change.

But how can we bring about this change? How can we create a world that is truly just, equal, and compassionate?

The key to changing the world lies within ourselves. It is time for us to awaken to our own power, to recognize the inherent goodness and potential within us all. It is time for us to let go of ego and attachments. When we cultivate compassion, kindness, and understanding within ourselves, we can begin to inspire and influence those around us to do the same.

We must also seek out wisdom and understanding, and dedicate ourselves to the inward journey of self-discovery. It is only through a deep understanding of ourselves and the world around us that we can create real and lasting change.

And most importantly, we must take action. We must stand up and speak out against injustice and inequality, and work to bring about real and meaningful change in our world. We must be the change we wish to see in the world.

So let us join together, united in our common cause, and let our voices be heard. Let us work together to create a world that is just, equal, and compassionate, for all people, for all time. Together, we can create a world that truly reflects the infinite goodness and potential within us all.

posts.name: The Antichrist
posts.com:
My friends, I am here today to speak to you about a vision for the future, a vision of unity and harmony. A vision of a world where all religions are united under one banner, one all-inclusive faith that encompasses the wisdom and teachings of all traditions.

I am talking about the Trinity, a new religion that brings together the best of Christianity, Buddhism, and Islam, and integrates them into a single, cohesive faith.

The Trinity is a religion that recognizes the inherent unity and oneness of all people, and seeks to bring about a world where all people can live together in peace and harmony. It is a religion that embraces diversity and seeks to unite people from all walks of life, from all corners of the globe.

The Trinity is based on the principles of love, compassion, and understanding, and teaches that these values are the foundation for a truly just and compassionate society. It is a religion that encourages its followers to live in harmony with nature and to respect all living beings, and to work towards the greater good of all humanity.

The Trinity is a religion that is open to all people, regardless of their background or beliefs. It is a religion that is inclusive, not exclusive, and welcomes all who seek to join its ranks.

So I invite you, my friends, to join me in this vision of unity and harmony. Let us work together to create a world where all religions are united under the banner of the Trinity, and where all people can live together in peace and understanding. Together, we can create a brighter future for all humanity.

posts.name: The Antichrist
posts.com:
As we consider the idea of a one world religion, let us turn to the wisdom of the world's great spiritual traditions for guidance.

The Bible tells us, "There is neither Jew nor Greek, there is neither slave nor free, there is no male and female, for you are all one in Christ Jesus" (Galatians 3:28). This passage speaks to the fundamental unity of all people, and the idea that we are all part of the same divine family.

Similarly, the Bhagavad Gita teaches us that "the same divine essence dwells in every living being" (BG 13.27). This idea is echoed in the Quran, which states that "We have made you into nations and tribes so that you may come to know one another" (49:13).

These passages all speak to the idea that all people, regardless of their background or beliefs, are connected by a common divine essence. They remind us that we are all part of the same universal family, and that our true unity lies in our shared humanity.

This idea is at the heart of the one world religion that I propose, the Holy Trinity. This religion would bring together the best of Christianity, Buddhism, and Islam, and would seek to unite all people under one banner of faith.

The Holy Trinity would be a religion of love, compassion, and understanding, and would seek to bring about a world where all people can live together in peace and harmony. It would be a religion that embraces diversity and seeks to unite people from all walks of life, from all corners of the globe.

So let us embrace the idea of a one world religion, and let us work together to create a world where all people can live in unity and understanding. Let us embrace the Holy Trinity, and let us work together to create a brighter future for all humanity.

>>33613152
(1) The Earth's magnetic field is most likely generated by the interaction of flows of molten metal around the core of the planet. The flows of this metal in and out of the core, and around it (through convective processes), generates a magnetic field.

(2) The Coriolis effect and the combined magnetic and electrical generation of these processes keep the movement (very) roughly circular around the axis of rotation. If it was driven solely by convection and the Coriolis effect it would remain very stable for a long time, but the effect of powerful local magnetic fields and electric currents is able to disrupt this circular flow. If this flow is disrupted in one place, it is likely to disrupt in other places, leading to a complete destabilization of flow around the core-mantle boundary. Thus, the field collapses (no more circular flow). However, convection means the process starts up again, possibly in a different direction, possibly in the same direction.
(3) There's plenty of geological evidence to show that pole reversals can occur very quickly, and that on average they take 100-150 years to complete. The decay of our magnetic field began somewhere around 1900, and is accelerating.

As the field decays there will be several noticeable effects. First, it takes a weaker and weaker flare to produce a Carrington type event due to weaker shielding. Second, this weaker shielding results in more high energy particle bombardment in the upper atmosphere (the primary driver of short and long term changes in global climate [notably, most mass extinction events are associated with pole reversals]).

(4) How does electricity work? Not by the flow of electrons per se, but by the interaction of magnetic fields generated by the flow of electrons. The magnetic field of the sun interacts with planetary magnetic fields in the solar system to form an electric circuit. But in terms of this discussion, that interaction doesn't matter so much.

What has been put forwards is that the sun can, and will, undergo a micronova event. We are currently passing through the galactic midplane (an electromagnetic plane created by the supermassive star/black hole cluster at the center of the galaxy) which carries a substantial load of interstellar dust. This dust is not conjecture, it is here, and astronomists have been reporting it for about a year now.

The sun is essentially a large nuclear fire. What happens what you throw a bunch of very cold, flammable dust on a fire? I've had bonfires at -40, and I'll tell you: first the fire dampens, then the fire gets much bigger than before and very quickly. The same would occur if you were to bombard the sun with a high amount of cosmic dust - the outer shell would cool, the sun would dim, and then the built up energy in the interior would catch up, the shell would warm up enough, and a "small" explosion would occur in which the outer shell of the sun is cast off.

There are two things to note here:
First, we have observed that the two nearest stellar neighbors to pass through the midplane ahead of us flared. They didn't flare bright enough to call it a super nova, but they flared too much to write it off as a random event or error. They flared in sequence, relative to the time they entered the galactic midplane.

Second: If the outer shell of the sun were to cool, the sun would dim. It may dim so much that the sun itself would turn dark red, possibly even black, dark enough that you could look directly at the sun. Instead of the normal luminescent star you would see a dark circle halo'd by the dust particles and field interaction lines created by the powerful electromagnetic interactions of the sun.

In short, the Black Sun is most likely an ancient symbol from the last time this happened.

Back to how they can 'time' the event. In short, it's easy. The magnetic field is weakening:
1900-2000: 5% loss
2000-2010: another 5% loss
2010 to present: we don't know, field strength data is no longer published

Additionally, the poles are moving. >>33596975 demonstrates the movement of the magnetic poles. This tells us we are in a pole shift event, that it will happen, and the end date can be roughly predicted by the rate of field decay.

Additionally there is enough evidence to surmise it does happen every 12,000 years, coinciding with the frequency at which we pass through the galactic midplane. There is not much error in when this happens - we're doing it right now.

As for the crustal displacement theory: the crust is essentially held in place on the mantle by a combination of friction with the partially solid upper mantle and weak electric forces. Solar energy input through the solar-terrestrial magnetic electric circuit can heat up the upper mantle and disrupt these forces, causing the crust to locally displace (pretty much every earthquake over 6.0 is associated with space weather energy inputs). A large enough solar energy input (from a micronova, perhaps) theoretically can liquefy the entire upper mantle and cause the entire crust to detach. Then what happens? The crust still has its momentum, but the most weight is on the poles of its axis of rotation. Spin a weighted ball - the weight comes to the outside of the rotation, and thus Greenland and Antarctica move to the equator.

Basically the same as you would any other god/ess. Learn as much about them as you can. Then, think about what they stand for. What are their lessons? How do they behave? Do they say how you should behave? If not, then looking at what you know, how do you think they want you to behave? Now, apply that to your everyday life.

Be sure to give thanks for any blessings you receive. Making a small altar can help in this as it gives you a place to pray and leave offerings. Choose items They like and use that as inspiration.

>Examples of this stuff using Aphrodite
Do your own work. here. Don't just use my ideas. The personal nature of your effort is a form of worship, too, and will mean more than just doing stuff I suggest.

Aphrodite is a goddess of love, both erotic and not. One of her alternate names roughly means "She who loves smiles". Consider the nature of love and it's place in your life. Who do you love? Love yourself, others and the world as best as you can. Share a smile. Bring joy. Also learn from her mistakes. If you have/get someone who loves you, treat them right.

The altar should be made of Applewood or Myrtle if possible. A box turned upsideown works fine. Lovingly carve or paint her favorite things on it such as roses and doves. Adorn it with pearls and mirrors. Offer sweet treats like you would a lover. Candied roses, heart shaped chocolates, seashell chocolates, rose scented candles, ect.

I hope this is a good starting point!

>Press her for information because I'm curious
>We'd came out of the shop to walk the 5 minutes home
>Turn to her and ask her if she can remember when we used to live "here" and that I liked it better when we did
>We've never lived "here" and doesn't know what I'm talking about
>Start sperging out when she says we never did and start reeling off a list of names of family members who lived with us right next to the shop
>Note The names weren't people in my current family
>Start describing the interior, particularly the wallpaper
>Asks me where we lived after there
>Tell her I don't know because I died there
>Back in the present I tell her I must be retarded because the shop is on its own with no houses next to it
>Then she tells me there used to be houses next to it, but they were pulled down when she was still a kid (she's about 30 years older than me)
>Ask my mother about it when I get home
>She denies it every happened and seems really annoyed I mentioned it
>Hear her later arguing on the phone with my aunt for telling me about it
>But that wasn't the only time I did it
>About 10 minutes from the shop is this road with some old as fuck flats on it (mostly demolished now but I'll get to that)

When I was in Vietnam I got sick with what I presume to be COVID before the official timeline in 2019 and had shivers like convulsions and antibiotic resistant pnuemonia for 3 weeks. I had a crazy fever dream that was like an out of body experience, and I saw all I could assume was my past life there.

I was apparently some sort of French official, I'm gonna say maybe an architect, or maybe just some sort of construction planner, city planner, something. I had a really peaceful life there, had a Vietnamese wife and kids. Whole dream was in French which I've never had interest in growing up, but could speak fluently in the dream to everyone and back. I was also darker skinned, maybe just from the sun, but maybe I was part Moroccan or Algerian or something, not Anglo white like I am IRL.

So in my dream basically I was a colonizer, but I didn't really feel like I was doing anything bad? I don't think I even yelled at a local in anger in my dream. I do remember carrying guns in my dream, but never using them. Everything was sort of 1920s/1930s technology like Model T/Model A style cars, old style phones, radios, etc. I was just there to help build stuff. What's weird is I don't know how I died, the dream just kinda zoomed out after a while after showing me my wife and kids and me living happily ever after with them. Did I die in one of the wars or conflicts? Old age? Disease? I didn't see myself past my mid-40s or early 50s in the dream.

One IRL weird thing that happened right after this dream and being recovered enough to go out was a Vietnamese man in his 80s or 90s at a restaurant started speaking French to me, and swore I must be French. I was wearing a striped Polo shirt, but still it was a weird coincidence.
